title: Wheel Hub for Power Window Motor

description.text: This wheel hub was designed to fit inside the Power window motors for sale by American Science & Surplus. They were originally for a Chrysler, but based on pictures I have seen of other assemblies, it looks like it might work in many modern motors based on the dorman design. http://www.sciplus.com/p/DRIVER-SIDE-MOTOR_52778 On the label on the motor, it says 402430 is the part number. These will work in both left and right side motors. My purpose is to connect these to common lawnmower wheels for a robot platform. Included is an adapter to do so. But I have also included the sketchup source file and you can use the adapter as base for your own adapter. Share whatever you build! The gear pops off these motors and are coupled by a rubber damper. Remove the gear and install this hub in its place. 2mm holes provided (2 per stud) to both allow mounting of an adapter and to stiffen the studs with the inserted screws.

author: victorjung

title: Nanode - a Network Applications Node based on Arduino technology

description.text:
Nanode provides lowest cost web interconnectivity for microcontrollers and smart sensor networks.
It is compatible with the Arduino programming environment. 
It combines ATmega328, ENC28J60 ethernet controller and magjack ethernet connector on the same small pcb. All components are conventional through-hole so that it can be assembled by anyone with basic soldering skills.  It can be built for under Â£20 (US$32) which is half the cost of an Arduino with ethernet shield.
The Nanode has additional I/O connectors which bring all of the I/O from the ATmega328 microcontroller and power to the top edge of the pcb. This allows it to be plugged direrectly into a standard breadboard making prototyping easier. 
It is compatible with most Arduino shields -such as the Nokia 3310 display shield shown'  
In addition to ethernet connectivity, Nanodes can be connected together on a low cost wired serial bus which allows them to be distributed around the home, for example, in a home automation or energy monitoring system. The serial bus allows Nanodes to communicate with one another or via a Master/Slave heirarchy. The Master device normally has the ethernet connection, and may also have real time clock, User display/interface SDcard storage etc. 
The Nanode platform is an ideal project to introduce web connectivity and networking.  It's low cost and ease of assembly makes it an ideal college or Hackspace project.
Nanode allows applications for internet remote montoring and control to be developed on a familiar low cost platform Applications such as web servers, web clients or for data exchange and control using services such as Pachube.
Nanode is based on an earlier ATmega/ENC28J60 design and firmware by Tuxgraphics.

Build instructions are on my Blog here: http://sustburbia.blogspot.com/2011/03/nanode-just-make-it.html and more details including parts lists, pcb prices etc on the London Hackspace Wiki here: http://wiki.hackspace.org.uk/wiki/Project:Nanode A spreadsheet of the parts list from Cool Components and Rapid Electronics in the UK is included below - for batch of 10 and 20 units. A firmware library which handles the ATmega/ENC28J60 commands has be written by Andrew Lindsay. It includes examples of a Twitter client, DNS queries and a Pachube client - which allows CSV data to be retrieved from Pachube. The download library and more detaiils can be found here: http://blog.thiseldo.co.uk/?p=504

description.text: I might need dinosaurs later for my tabletop game, but instead of modeling from scratch, I grabbed these from around the internet and made them miniature ready gaming! The Brontosaurus was made my me. The Hadrosaurus is actually a remix of this guy: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2288937 The Stegosaurus is a remix of this fella: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:12078 The Velociraptor and Deinonycus are from here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1142519 The Dimetrodon is from this fella: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:332123 The T-Rex is from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:135530 by sk8nmike. I fixed up the eyes, and sized it for the "huge" size category. The Triceratops is from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:182327 by YahooJAPAN. I sized him down for the "huge" size category. The Allosaurus is from http://www.123dapp.com/catch/Dion/2556663 by Mat Paris. It was a pretty massive file, so I brought down the face count, fixed up the teeth and eyes, and sized him up for the "large" size category. The Ankylosaurus is from http://www.123dapp.com/123C-3D-Model/Ankylosaurus/656380 by "Autodesk Premium". I sized it down for the "huge" category, and brought down the face count some. The Plesiosaurus was originally an Elasmosaurus model from http://www.123dapp.com/123C-3D-Model/Elasmosaurus/597287 by "Autodesk Premium". I made the head larger, shrunk down the neck, and matched the face to line up with a Pleasiosaurus skull. Then I modeled a stand for it and altered the body to fit in it. Finally the Pteranodon was from http://www.123dapp.com/3dcr-Creature/Pteranodon/1896559 by Riccardo Bragalini. I sized it down for the "medium" size catagory, and made a stand for it after altering the body some.
Use supports and try to print them on their backs as much as possible.

New version with USB port is uploaded.
If you have encountered the mounting or read error issue of Viki LCD V1.0 SD Card Reader, please see some of my suggestions sharing with you under the Instructions tab.

Tips for setting up the SD Card Reader of Viki LCD v1.0 with Azteeg x3 v2.0 on Repetier Firmware 0.91v8 and 0.92v9 for the Kossel Mini 3D Printer: A) For Compilation Error Issue:
1) Compile and upload the firmware by Arduino v1.6.9.
B) For SD Card Detection Issue:
1) Revise the SDCARDDETECT to -1 in configuration.h
2) Revise the SDCARDDETECT to -1 in the pins.h for AZTEEG_X3
3) Revise the SDCARDDETECT to -1 in the ui.h for Viki Lcd
C)For SD Card Read Error Issue of Viki LCD:
1) Revise the UI_I2C_CLOCKSPEED to 80000L in the ui.h for Viki Lcd
2) Revise the SPI_FULL_SPEED to SPI_HALF_SPEED in the SDCard.cpp
3) Search for "SD Read Error" at gcode.cpp and then replace those retry codes as follows:
UI_ERROR("SD Read Error");
// Start of my re-try codes //
// Re-try in case of recoverable errors
int err_cnt = 0;
do
{
sd.file.seekSet(sd.sdpos);
n = sd.file.read();
err_cnt = err_cnt + 1;
}
while(n == -1 and err_cnt < 30);
if(n == -1)
{
Com::printErrorFLN(PSTR("SD error did not recover!"));
UI_ERROR("SD error did not recover!");
sd.sdmode = 0;
// Kill hotend, bed temperature, fan and re-home
GCode::executeFString(PSTR("M104 S0\nM140 S0\nG28\nM107"));
break;
}
// End of my re-try codes //
UI_ERROR("SD error fixed");

title: Bowden e3d v6 screw-on mount (for 3up) + Fan Duct

description.text:
Based on the idea of leafguys Bowden mount for 3up, this e3d v6 mount fixates the heat sink by pressure.  
Might work on other printers where you want to replace a NEMA17 direct drive.  
Added 19. Sept. 2015: Fan Duct

Simply print the bottom and the top part.
I printed mine with 30% 3D-Honeycomb infill (from Slic3r), looks sturdy enough so far. Use 30mm M3 bolts and hex nuts to apply the pressure.
My nema17 steppers are also held by m3. If you need bigger holes, or other sizes somewhere, edit the scad or ask me to add a parameter for that :) I built-in a parameter for oversizing the mount fittings, because some material tends to expand a little, leaving smaller gaps then intended.
My own mount is using option 2. Fan Duct seems best printed with the fan mount as bottom and the "chimney" going up in 45°.
It is designed for mounting on the right (front view), but you can use your host/slic3r to simply mirror it for mounting on the left.

title: Printrbot Simple Metal GT2 Belt Clip

description.text:
Simple Belt Clip Noticed that the default cable tie method, as per instructions leads to slippage in belt tension over time... Top Tip...
The screw that holds the belt in the hole at the extruder end of the Y axis in the instructions (Step 24). Is not long enough (M3 10mm), put a longer one in to avoid the belt pulling it at and angle. then when fitting the Y arm just use a shorter screw on the opposite side or just miss it out...
Reference:
http://help.printrbot.com/Guide/Printrbot+Metal+Simple+%28Model+1403%29+Rev+F+Printrboard/151 WARNING:
You must secure the clip it with a cable tie... NOTE:
Please make sure you fit them with the same orientation as shown on both ends of the belt, (base facing away from stepper motors), otherwise you will have interference issues...

There are 3 files i'm uploading. The first File is HD_Logo. ( all 1 piece stl file) Then there are HD_Logo_R_1 & HD_Logo_R_2. This splits the base and letters into 2 pieces. When you drop these 2 files into your slicer program, don't rescale! Don't move position!, until both files have been imported. Then move them as a pair to platform, then convert Inches to MM. I did this in makerware desktop. I did this in PLA @ 210C sliced @ .2mm layers with 2 shells and 15% infill. It took about an hour on my CTC 3d Printer. Check it out here: https://youtu.be/I9L1FT3jsyA

title: Inline skate wheel 70mm rubber + ABS / PLA / NYLON

description.text: this is a simple wheel for inline skate, can be printed with a double extruder with rubber (TCP flex is better) and ABS, PLA or NYLON for the inside wheel; or can use the old rim to rework the wheel with resin like sintagom 703/80 reasult shore A 80/82 wheel

09/04/2015 i have upload a new mold for the rubber, with better degassing system and less plastic used (about 50g of PLA each part of the mold if 30% infill 4 perimeters) data for molding with sintagom: mold weight: 100g
wheel weight: 44.2
rubber weight: 26.5
rubber + wheel weight: 70.7 sintagom: 30g part A 12g part B (a bit in excess for stay sure)

We use these fake eggs to encourage our hens to lay eggs. When I was a kid we called them "seed eggs," but that term does not seem to be used much any more.  
These eggs are the right size and shape for Cuckoo Maran chickens. Rhode Island Red eggs are the same shape but about 1.1x larger.  
The shape was originally created in Inkscape and exported to OpenSCAD for extrusion.

title: Heavy Duty (a.k.a. overkill) Phone mount for Prusa i3 P3steel

description.text:

remixed_from.author: BigBadBison
remixed_from.title: Makerfarm Prusa i3v Spool Holder Extension

title: MakerFarm Prusa i3v Dual Spool Holder with Optional Filament Guide

description.text: I've upgraded to Clough42's excellent Itty Bitty Dual Extruder and needed space for a second spool. I've had great success using BigBadBison's Spool Holder Extension for several months now and expanded on his design to accommodate two rolls. I've included files for a center post with an integral filament guide, and one without, as well as the extended spindle and base. This design continues to use the original MakerFarm wood side posts and spacer. You will need to also provide an M3x16 bolt and nut for the center upright (I had them left over from my original build).

I printed these in ABS for the strength and the decreased friction against the spools and filament.
  • Important: Some of these parts are almost 9 inches long, so take care when plating. You should probably have at least a 7x7 printable area to fit them on the diagonal.
    • The Filament Guide piece prints upright and has a very narrow base, so if you've already got your dual extruder set up, I recommend orienting it perpendicular to your nozzles to help make sure the idle nozzle doesn't knock over your piece.

comments.text:
Tried to print this once, colossal belt jumping failure. Why? Because my Y-axis home point was so far off it was a joke. I'll be trying again, this time with a properly setup printer. This is definitely a print that stretches the capabilities and tests the proper adjustment of your printer.
Thanks for giving this to us!

description.text:
And yet another version of a box to hold this popular board.  
Two box versions are included, one with mounting lugs and one without.  
I printed the top in clear so that you can see the internal LEDs. Areas in the top are thinner than others to help let the light shine through.  
The top and box have matching dimples and protrusions to snap the top on . Works well on my print. YMMV  
I have made a slight modification to the top mounts to make them more robust. Works "more better".

Box was printed with .2 mm layers. 25% infill.  
Top needs to be printed with .1 mm layers 100% infill.  
PLA was used for both parts.  
The button extensions are pieces of 3mm filament that I first flattened the end with a hot soldering iron. Next insert them from the backside of the top. Snap the top to the box and push the filament until it touches the switch and then cut the filament off about 4-5mm above the surface of the top and then use a hot soldering iron to mushroom the end of the filament. They are now captive.  
To straighten the filament for the button extensions, I simply placed a piece of filament on the heat bed while the top was printing and the filament straightened itself out.

comments.text: You multiplied your measurement by 5.  I've assembled the stl parts on a cad program and got the shoulder axis distance of 287mm.  Shoulder pins are 8mm by my calculations.  You dxf had the pins at 40mm, so dividing by 8 I got 5.  Dividing the your axis distance of 1433.89mm by 5 I got  286.778.  So scaling down by 5 should fix it. The other problem is the there is a difference in the shoulder axis between the front plate and the back plate.  The corresponding measurement being 1435.36mm. Big difference here but when scaled down the difference is 0.294mm.  That's a fairly big misalignment over the short distance of 56mm front to back.

I needed something to help my housemates and I know whether one of us had fed our cats that day*, so I made this.  
After one of us has fed the loudly meowing cats, we move a little stone to the box for today.  
It can be used in place of any whiteboard daily covered with "Did "  (though you'll have to change the "Cats fed" text in my messy .scad).   
*Because they meow at you even after they've been fed

I printed at 40% infill, with 2 perimeters, and 3 solid top and bottom layers, but really, anything should work (I'd be interested to know if any settings "break" the thing).  
Stick it to the wall with double sided tape.  
Tell your cats (with certainty) to shut their furry traps (until tomorrow).

remixed_from.author: sam0737
remixed_from.title: Minimized heavy duty printable filament spool

description.text:
UPDATE
26 APR 2013 Finally finished a useable full-size prototype of this design...
First thought: "Ohh crap the hub is backwards..." Problem solved! Second Thought: "Hmm... It makes the filament bundle into a triangle..." Give it 4 arms instead of 3! Third Thought: Cookies for everyone! I added those 2 STLs (tri and now QUAD hubs corrections/additions) and will post a video/tutorial when I get my next bit of good PLA in... I am not happy with the BLUE that I currently have to work with, it is very finicky and difficult. Have a glorious and victorious day. 20 APR 2013
It's safe to say this is a useable, viable, and durable doo-hicky!
I got a chance to sit at my printer again and tweak my calibration as I was preparing to use a different brand and color of PLA to print this design. I bought plastic that actually came on a spool so I could print... a SPOOL! Indeed... Well the bad news is, I need a better bed than this painters tape shenanigans. The good news is- it didn't matter at all that the print warped a bit, everything works perfectly! I posted a video to explain everything better.
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Cx1Xh1OjD5k Changes to come soon, as well as a "build tutorial" when I actually print an entire spool haha. Enjoy! 18 APR 2013
**I have increased the size of the "peg holes" to 2.20mm
I realigned them as well to make things more efficient.
Also implemented my "filament end" clip-in spot on the hands.
Last, but not least; I made 2 hands, one short and one long, I realized that the smallest form of this still did not fit my LayWood roll, which was its intended purpose in the first place - it should now! Be sure to print one of everything to see how it all works out for you! Message me if any changes should be implemented... Cheers This has been designed to be locked into 4+ different positions, using anything 1.65-1.80 mm... (By the by, I use something 1.75mm all the time!) I imagine zipties, or twist ties, or anything of the like will work I am in the process of printing the first Arm/Hand pair right now!
**UPDATE**
I finished (mostly) the first set of Arms, Ends, and Support Pieces...
It looks like everything works rather nicely, except the part that matters... the spot for the "filament pegs" was a little too 'blobbed' and i don't have anything to clear it out. Will readjust the design and reprint probably tomorrow. If you have got a small enough drill bit to clear those holes out, by all means Print Away! Let me know what alterations are going to be needed... I can think of a couple right now, but I want to see it in use first! Cheers! This is a Derivative of the "Minimized" Heavy Duty Filament Spool (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:69602)

Haven't finished printing it myself yet, but did a test/prototype and it seems solid! I updated these files with better tolerances... Feel free to request the old files or any modifications to the old ones. Happy Printing!

comments.text: It's intended to hold filament that may be sold to you in a loose coil. Not all filament comes on a nice pretty spool, this is meant to solve the variations to what type of coils a seller might send you.

title: Hexagon and Alu-Extruder Carriage for DaVinci

description.text:
Just as the title says: You can now rid yourself of that awful, stock, hotend / extruder combo! I've created this part specifically for RepRapDiscount's Hexagon Hotend and Printrbot's Aluminum Extruder. Plus, with its unique "Clip-On" design, you no longer have to dismantle your entire printer to replace, maintain or modify your carriage.
It runs extremely cool - the heat sync is cool to the touch. I have now put approximately 12 hours on the carrier, 6 of which have been in PLA. I have tested up to 60mm/s with no issues, and more specifically no clogging. Additional Note: For those willing to take a well worth it risk, here are all of the parts i bought:
  • Hexagon Hotend Kit: http://www.reprapdiscount.com/hotends/67-hexagon-hotend-set.html
  • Alu-Extruder: http://printrbot.com/shop/printrbot-alu-extruder-2/
  • Bonus part: .3mm Nozzle: http://www.makerfarm.com/index.php/3mm-hexagon-nozzle-for-1-75mm-filament.html
    • Update:
    Unfortunately, I have lost the original IPT for this part after transferring computers. Consequently, I can no longer make edits to it, so it is no longer a "work-in-progress". However, I will be working on a new carriage assembly in the weeks to come (sadly I have many studies that also demand my attention).
    In the next built I plan to address some of the small "bugs" I have noticed in this one, so please check back! Any recommendations are welcome.

Download and print 1 Carrier1.stl and 2 Carrier_Clip2.stl files, and you're set! For some reason all of my Inventor files need to be scaled by 10. I recommend printing the carriage right side up with minimal supports and the clips on their side. The hotend will slide directly up from the bottom of the carrier and clip into the Aluminum Extruder. Also, use the 5v Davinci fan - not the 12v fan that comes with the Hexagon hotend. Both of the clips you printed will screw to the bottom of the carrier with the screws that came with the Hexagon (there is a small slit for the belt that will indicate direction). Everything else simply screws into the carrier as I have shown in my pictures above. Good luck, post your makes!

comments.text: Did a rework added bearings,fan for when printing PLA. Also Added hole to route extruder element wires to go through center of carriage.

description.text: This pattern is made for an egg. Can be plotted by using an EggBot.
Print it using the layers option of the EggBot printer software for each color.

I've designed, built and tested a (relatively) compact geared extruder.
The gearing is 9:31, which doesn't sound much - but the drive is an M4 bolt, so the gearing is much more than you need.

I used an M4x40 cap screw (left over from the mendel build) for the drive, making use of a locknut within the drive gear. You could easily turn the gear around, and use an M4 hex bolt instead. The drive is transferred to the nut / bolt head using three M3 set screws - so there should be no problems with torque transfer. For the hobbing I used an M7x1.0 tap on the shank of the M4 cap screw... but I'm sure other choices of tap would work. The second photo shows the important bits of the drive bolt. Basically, the order is (from left to right): nyloc, gear, nut, nut, washer, bearing, washer, hobbed gap, washer, bearing, washer, bolt head. Don't think everything in that photo is correct: I had the M3 screws mounting the base the wrong way round, you need to put the two right hand M4 bolts for the idle block in before you attach the motor and the mounting screws to the carriage should be M4x16. But the drive is correct. As I'm using a stainless steel heat barrier, I used base.stl as a template for drilling holes in a sheet of aluminium, to act as a heat sink. Depending on your hot end design, you probably want to tweak the base anyway. The assembled extruder is contained in the openscad file - so you can look at how things fit easily. Finally, the openscad file can be used to generate a low warp version of the bearing mount (tested), or one using MR84 bearings (untested). The licence doesn't apply to parametric_involute_gear_v5.0.scad - that file is GPL ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3575 )

I'm going through several upgrades to my video equipment and decided to add a video monitor to my camera tripod. The mounting arm adapter would not clamp onto the tripod legs because of their size. What I needed was a spacer that would clamp to the tripod leg that has a "D" shape. I designed the part using Design Spark Mechanical (love the SW) and it works great!!!!

Only one part is included in the stl. What I did in CURA was to load the stl and then make a copy of it. I then used the mirror function on the second object and told CURA to make a mirror image of it on the X axis. This allows you to have a perfect mirror image of your original object. Works great. Give it a try if you need to make parts that are a mirror image of each other.  
Printed with PLA .2mm layers 25% infill. I used 3mm screws and nuts.

I made Vitting's thing http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:589647 and it worked well for me except one of the end caps that keeps the power supply in place snapped off. That wasn't really a problem. I used it in that state until the cable clip on the charge cable itself broke (Microsoft didn't do as good of job as Apple does with theirs) and then Vitting's wasn't useful to me anymore. So, I made a remix. This one has a built in clip on the bottom. It is a little thicker all around and is one piece. You will have to use support regardless of how you print it.
I used ABS with 100% infill.  I wanted mine to be very strong.  The bar that holds the power supply in place needs to be able to bend out of the way so PLA may be a problem with this design.

comments.text:

A simple pine build out of stars. Let it grow small or high, just how you like. But beware of mother nature's laws of physics. No support required, just print. If you are up for a challenge try building the highest standing Star Pine. Will yours reach the stars up high or will it crumble down low? Printing a Star Pine: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wm_L8xCog9o

No support required, just print. Can also be printed larger. A Tree grows as following:
  • Trunk-Normal or Trunk-Long
  • Star
  • ...
  • Star
  • Star-Small
  • Star-Smaller
  • Star-Smallest
    • Stars-plate gives you all the stars you need for a small Star Pine. You can then let it grow higher with more normal Stars.

This is a single piece prop balancer, that can fit up to 10" props spinning all the way around. I wanted a one piece design for alignment and accuracy at the expense of portability/storage space. For use with: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B001BHK54W/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o04_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1 (or any other figertip balancer with the same axle length, approximately 1.92in/48.8mm) Also need 1/4 in magnets, I had these sitting around: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0012AUU84/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Printed with ABS, 10% infill, 3 layer top/bottom/perimeter. After printing, glue the magnets into the slots, I recommend a hot glue stick but any adhesive will do. Finally put the prop balancer on with your prop and spin and balance. Also I recommend sanding the backside of the prop over applying tape. From a materials, structural, and aerodynamic point of view, its a safer bet. You remove an extremely thin layer of material, and can be much more precise than with tape.

A simple screw together rack which supports a standard filament roll on some bearings.  
Designed for my Davinci 1.0A.   
The rack fits on the right hand side ands two tabs which fix it in position in the notices on the base of the printer.   
Bearings are 8mm OD by 3mm ID, two on each axle making a flanged roller.  
Fixings should be M3 10mm, preferably countersunk on the tabbed side as its a tight squeeze.

Print all the bits in one go, took about 4 hrs on my Davinci 1.0A with 15% infill and all other settings standard.  
Possibly a little flimsy, so i"d up the infill if making another.  
Use M3 screws to fix together, remembering to put the roll on before fitting the brace through the middle of the spool.  
Any bearings would do the trick, I have used 8x3 ball bearings as I had them knocking around.   
Once made and with spool. align tabs with the notches on the side of the printer base and push the spool down. Its a tight fit to make sure it doesn't move around.... it will fit, just push it.  
Designed and built for a 92mm wide spool, a couple of washers may be needed to accommodate wider spools, and narrower can be taken by using longer bearing axles.  
Work in progress......

description.text:
The model is used for testing the quality of printing of your Form 1+ if you can print all the 11 parts of this model without any problem your Form 1+ is perfectly calibrated.
See all the things tested in this model in the instructions. Please note: The model have been developed using Formlabs Design Guide for Formlabs Clear resin and printing at 100 microns.
http://formlabs.com/media/upload/formlabs-design-guide.pdf

If you want to print from the .stl file generate internal support and add them manually on the circle. This model tests :
The minimum supported wall thickness
The minimum unsupported wall thickness
The maximum unsupported overhang lenth
The minimum unsupported overhang angle
The maximum horizontal support span/bridge
The minimum vertical-wire diameter
The minimum embossed detail
The minimum engraved detail
The minimum clearance
The minimum hole diameter
The minimum drain hole diameter

Headphone rest I designed for my bluetooth headphones.
Connector pieces are slimmer than the grooves in the legs, so they fit easily.
I recommend using a tiny drop of glue to hold the pieces together.

Foot ball goal post, made for cake decoration not sure what else it could be used for. :) Link to tinkercad, if you want to modify it.
https://tinkercad.com/things/lX9wrNAm6Mh

  • Glue it to make a goal post as shown in picture
  • Probably you could also use Zip tie

title: Cable Carrier
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a cable carrier for a cnc machine/robot. Probably 3D printable on a makerbot/reprap or similar, even though there are overhangs, most are not important structural parts. If anyone needs a larger version then this is possible. In the next week or so I will upload the mounting blocks to attach it to the desired part of your machine.
I've included the original source files (.ipt) for Autodesk Inventor users.
Enjoy :[)

may need some minor clean up....
Just print and repeat, they should snap together, holes may need to be widened. ABS cools faster and I reccomend a fan as they are small, plus maybe adding a minimum layer time to help overhangs cool. They ARE SMALL PIECES.
Also ABS has more flexibility than PLA which will mean connecting pieces will be easier.

title: The Cheapest Whiteboard - By Atomic Lab

description.text: Extracted from: https://www.facebook.com/theatomiclab [Whiteboard for $ 6 by Atomic Lab] #TheCheapestWhiteboardintheworld The cost of a whiteboard is greater than $ 60 (as seen in the photos). From Atomic Lab find a solution so that everyone can have their board to practice maths. Can you imagine being able to practice again and again the exercises without wasting sheets? #Education 3.0! How you make your board? In Argentina we got a plate 50x70 cm Acetate to (Arg Peso) $27. In addition, we need a white plate of any material 2mm thick (I use high impact $ 25. The overlapping plates would like the photo). Now we need them to stay still, for that we turn to the #3DPrinting, here we leave the files to print. We are united and ready! Our idea is to make these boards to reach more people, kids who need them, if you want help or you like to have a whiteboard like this send an email to [email protected] Thank you for sharing!

[Pizarra para fibrones por 6 dólares por Atomic Lab​] #LaPizarraMasBarataDelMundo El costo de una pizarra es mayor a 600$ (como se ve en las fotos). Desde Atomic Lab encontramos una solución para que todos puedan tener su pizarrón y poder practicar. Te imaginas poder practicar una y otra vez los ejercicios sin desperdiciar hojas? #Educación 3.0! Como realizas tu pizarrón? En Argentina conseguimos una placa de 50x70 cm de Acetato a 27$. Ademas, necesitamos una placa blanca de cualquier material con 2mm de espesor (Utilizamos alto impacto, 25$. Las placas superpuestas quedarían como la foto). Ahora necesitamos que se queden quietas, para eso recurrimos a la #Impresion3D, acá te dejamos el link para que bajes e imprimas los perfiles y el soporte para el fibrón. Lo unimos y esta listo! Nuestra idea es hacer que estos pizarrones lleguen a mas personas, a chicos que necesiten como a #escuelas de "emergencia", si te interesa ayudarnos o te gustaría tener un #pizarrón como este envianos un mail a [email protected] Gracias por compartir!

This thing was inspired by the Lulzbot Taz Enclosure by MrMcGuire. I've attached a dxf file of the panel details of my enclosure make, so you may have them laser cut, or you can use it as a guide to cut them yourself. Please note the dxf file is not optimized to minimize material, you may want to rearrange the drawing to do so. Also I've attached my version of MrMcGuire's corner bracket and L bracket, which had minor issues with the holes and the hole pattern was slightly inconsistent. Also my version of the MrMcGuire enclosure adds a side door. While I have attached the stl files for the corrected corner and L brackets, the rest of the required printed components can be found at MrMcGuires' thing page : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:675652 If you use the attached dxf file for your panels, be sure to use the attached corrected version of the corner bracket and the L bracket, or you may have alignment issues. Update 9-18-2015 I have created a removable bed system perfect for using with this enclosure. Check it out! http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1021403 Update 2-18-2016 I have added the corrected L bracket to the file section. The holes on this part were also slightly skewed and my DXF file uses the corrected hole pattern. If you use the dxf file to make your panels be sure to use my versions of the L bracket and corner bracket on this thing's page.

I used 2 shells and 35% infill. On the door hinges (see MrMcGuires thing) I printed the top 60% of the hinge with the rod at 100% infill. They will see a lot of stress. I used pololu.com to laser cut my acrylic. It was expensive, but the quality was superb. This thing fit together perfectly. Pololu shipped it exactly in the time they quoted, and the panels came packaged well and in perfect condition. You may want to increase the height of the enclosure from what my drawings show by 3". Mine is 24" tall and the filament tube will impinge on the ceiling for taller prints. It still works fine though. And this enclosure is really big already. You could reduce the width by 2" as well without an issue. (from 34.5" to 32.5"). Finally I supply two potential vent fan locations (designed for 50x50mm dc fan), top or lower back. Also in the back is a hole for the stock power supply cable, as well as any other cabling you might require. The lulz_enc_cap.stl file is supplied if you want to plug one or both of the stock fan locations. Hardware requirements: I used #10 stainless steel socket cap head screws (or 4mm) with locknuts (nylon insert) and black nylon washers. I used 7/8" long but you could go .75" (18 to 25mm long is ok). If you use my handle print for your enclosure you'll need at least 7/8" long (22-25mm) for those screws. You will need well over 100 screws and nuts (about 150), best to buy two boxes of 100 each, and if you want a washer on both sides you'll need to buy 300 washers. Also I should mention I used the Taz nosepliers for a lot of the nuts, because there isn't always enough room to use a socket unfortunately. It was a slow and tedious process. But the enclosure is fantastic I really like it. Another side benefit, it cuts the noise of printing down to almost nothing. Update 3-31-2015 I have uploaded a new thing http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:749036 which is the exhaust fitting designed to mount to this enclosure. See thing for more details. Update 4-1-2015 I have uploaded a new thing: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:752281 which is a handle which may connect on both sides of the enclosure for easier lifting and moving. Update 12-6-2015 I have created another exhaust fitting, for attaching the McMaster-Carr hose to the wall, over a dryer vent: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1178146

comments.text: The original enclosure was designed to be cut from a single sheet of 4' x 8' acrylic. It doesn't seem possible to upload a file in the comments but I re-aligned the parts in the dxf file so that this is true. The new part layout takes advantage of the natural edges of the 4'x8' sheet as well as adjoining edges of similarly sized parts. From a local industrial laser cutting shop I have gotten a quote that is less than half of what is mentioned here from online cutters. The job isn't done yet so take that for what it's worth. Biggest factors in laser cutting are cut time and materials so the more you can reduce these the cheaper it is. Also, if you just have a loose set of parts that aren't aligned to specific material sizes, you are leaving it up to the cutter to select what panel size they get cut out from. You could end up paying for a fair amount of unused/wasted material.

title: Stackable Coke bottle windmill (VAWT) for bottle dynamo

description.text:
Real Quick and simple to make, VAWT for charging of AA batterys and USB stuff.  
Print out STL and recycle or drink 6 / 2lt coke bottles, cut each in half leaving the screw neck intact. Load into  coke bottles  into holder and press fit onto a 6V 3W bottle dynamo, this one is made to fit a bottle dynamo I allready had.  
stack them on top of each other to get the power needed, for a given wind speed.  
With load matching circuits we could boost the output to around 5w.  
could also make big stack, and finish with another bottle dynamo on the other end, I will make a endstop version of the block so you can have big stacks and 2 bottle dynamos. ~ 10w boosted  
you could probley go down to your local bike shop, and get find a few that they have not tossed out. I did and got a crate full!! for the sake of some plastic, your 3D printer, and a few recycled bottles you can charge you AA batterys and USB stuff with the circuits I have. Electronics would be less than $5 to buy parts for a AA charger and USB charger.   
I will make a hub dynamo version soon, and add the 'base' to hold common dynamos, for being driven from the coke bottle VAWT  
NOT PRINT TESTED

author: TeitelBot

description.text:
Weâ€™ve been experimenting with mechanical motions borrowed from braiding machines and figured out a way to lasercut and assemble a hand-cranked version. There are â€œboatsâ€ that are carried through a track by a disc attached to intersecting gears, making them go around in an extended 8-shape pattern. Itâ€™s not really done yet, tweaking and expanding still remains - feel free to do so. But we think the hardest part is solved, figuring out the pathing and â€œbehaviourâ€ of the boats. Check out the blog post:
http://skrekkogle.tumblr.com/post/47786975099/motion-study-experiments http://www.skrekkogle.com

-The device needs to be cut from a 3mm plate. We used acrylic, because the low friction, but we guess other materials could work as well.
-There are just the one layer in the illustrator file, before cutting the holes and edges should be separated.
-The "boats" have been iterated upon; since we only did one round of laser cutting we cheated a bit and 3d printed the base of these. Stl and editable 3d-files are included.
-If a piece is loose in it's slot, we recommend using a transparent silicone glue, that is slightly elastic.

This is a sort of quickstart manual-in-a-script series that will show you how to generate gcode from math using Python and provide a "foot in the door" for more complex parametric prints. para_01.py:
The hello world of 3D parametric printing, this prints a prism shape by doing nothing more than moving the print head to three points and then raising it one layer. para_02.py:
Adding trig functions, this script moves from straight lines to circles to print a cylinder. para_03.py:
In the most advanced example in this pack, the GCode object is given a "rotate" method so that the cross-section of the model can be rotated one step at a time. I'll make another one of these with more advanced lessons later-- there are a LOT more things that can be done with this than I've shown here!

Download, run from your skeinforge directory, view the results on skeinview to be sure no trouble is due, then print!
For further interest, fiddle with the math, cross sections, etc to create a wide variety of patterns!

description.text:
My dishwasher doesn't dry the dishes very well, I end up with puddles of water on top of coffee mugs.  If I leave the door open, the water evaporates when I am away at work, and when I am back, everything is nice and dry.  However, I don't want to leave the dishwasher door fully open, cause then dust will blow in.  So I thought I'd make a little dishwasher door prop opener :-)  
The clip opening is 23.5mm wide, that's the height of the top lip of my dishwasher.  The part above the clip is 13.5mm high, that's the gap between the top of my dishwasher and the bottom of the counter top.

I sliced it with Slic3r, printed it with my Craftbot. Settings below:
  • white cheap PLA, 210 C extruder / 60 C bed
  • 0.2 mm layer height
  • 100% first layer height
  • 3 vertical shells, 3 layer top/bottoms
  • 20% honeycomb infill
  • rectilinear top/bottom shells
  • 50 mm/s perimeters
  • 15 mm/s small perimeters
  • 50% external perimeters
  • 50 mm/s infill
  • 20 mm/s solid infill
  • 15 mm/s top solid infill
  • 90 mm/s travel
  • 30 mm/s first layer speed
  • 50% first layer extrusion width (all others 0 in advanced screen)
  • 15% infill/perimeter overlay
    • It took about 1.5 hr to print, fits first time!
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/9aSfh2K4Gv0

JIM, son of ZOWI, son of BOB, a biped robot based on Arduino.
Entirely designed in FreeCad for ZUMBT328 and Futaba S3003 servos. More info at http://diwo.bq.com/en/jim-cc-by-sa/

comments.author: gianakop

comments.text:
No we need one nemea 17 mount and one nemea 23 mount. The nemea 23 mount is obligatory because that mount give us the ability to slide the entire robotic arm up and down according with egg's size and geometry!
I strongly suggest that mount if you want use the eggbot in order to draw a bigger varity size of eggs (except hen's eggs). From very small eggs (e.g. guinea fowl egg) till bigger eggs (goose eggs).
comments.author: ElmoC

comments.text:
Hi Niko,
I really like your design, it's the best one that I have found. Thanks for sharing it. I am working on a slight remix using 2040 extrusions and more printed parts and have a few observations and questions.
The file "nikosEB_5_right.stl" has a damaged first layer. I mirrored the "nikosEB_5_left.stl" file to make a good copy to get it to print out but thought that you should know.
There is not enough space to mount the control board facing up as shown in your photos without modifying the 3 prong connection for the servo motor. May I ask how you accomplished this? I am using longer 3d printed legs and have the board mounted facing down to allow room for the servo plug.
I am also curious about the pen arm hinge shown in your photo. Is it the official Egg-bot hinge made of acetal?
comments.author: ayudtee

comments.text:
I've just uploaded a new file nikosEB_5_right_new.stl. I think that is right (thanks for your notice) !
I think the space is enough for the control board. Look cerefully (I added two larger images ) the way I have mounted the board.
The the pen arm hinge isn't the original.

title: XYZ Davinci 1.0 magnetic door catch spacer block

description.text: The plastic nubs that keeps the door closed on my printer finally all broke off so my door wouldn't stay closed.  I printed this little block with an indent in for a magnet.  I then glued it to the upper left corner of my door so it sticks to the metal frame.  Now my door stays closed.

You need to space it about 1/8" to the right (as you look at the outside of the door) to clear the plastic of the top front of the printer that sticks down in the top left of the door opening.  I used a drop of loctite gel control super glue to hold in the magnet and glue to the door.  The magnet I used was a 5/16" dia. 5/64" thick rare earth magnet.  I had to shave out the hole diameter just a little to make it a tight fit, but the depth printed perfect.

comments.text: Nice, I had done the exact same thing with a calibration cube!  My cat apparently has a plastic fetish and when I found him INSIDE my printer, I decided it was time to fix the door.  ;)
comments.author: Nepenthy

comments.text: I think my toddler yanking the door open to see if I have printed something for him is what did mine in finally.  He knows not to open it when it is running, but when it is quiet he thinks there must be a new toy in there for him.
comments.author: Nepenthy

title: Logitech C170 webcam mount for daVinci 3D Printer

description.text:
This mount is designed to fit the Logitech C170 webcam with the daVinci 1.0 printer.  It's clipped on the top and to the back and looks down on the bed from behind.  I wish the C170 camera had a wider FOV but webcams are usually very limited in that regard.  It works and I'm happy with it.  I chose the C170 because it works out of the box with Octoprint without any fiddling and it was inexpensive.  
I use the webcam with OctoPrint and monitor the jobs from the webui.  See attached video and images for vantage point.  
I've included the SketchUp file so you can edit it and make changes.

Printed with daVinci printer with 0.35mm layer height and 10% fill.  I'm running repetier 0.92 with Octoprint.  
The gcode file is what I used to print it from Octoprint.

The island of St. Thomas constructed using 1 arcsecond resolution SRTM data from the Space Shuttle (about 1.7 million polygons). It was made using a new and, as yet, unreleased version of SRTM2STL. The source code for creating files at 3 arcsecond resolution is available up on github under the GNU license. Go to github and search for SRTM2STL.

You may want to print this to be relatively small. I used to get warping using PLA and it got bad when I try to print Raised Relief Maps that are big. Now that I have a heated bed, I get much better results.
